data.text: How to Keep Valuables Safe when Bike Touring?

Where do you carry your passport, cards, cash etc. when traveling by touring bike? On the bike, on your person, in a travel wallet, a belt, or what? Leaving soon on a tour and my wife is telling me to buy a waterproof pack that hangs around the neck. That just sounds uncomfortable. Advice appreciated. Thanks
A bar bag with a detachable strap. Easy to unclip and take with you into a shop. Dangerous to have anything hanging from your neck.
data.author: Mark Smith

data.text: Just put in a freezer zip lock bag and put in zipped pocket but do keep on you

data.text: Good advice. And have at least two different cards to access cash from ATMs, that way if an ATM swallows one card, you have another.

data.text: I ride with a medium size backpack carrying water, fruit, a snack, wind jacket and my passport. Cash and card I a small wallet in a front deep pocket or a ziped one.

data.text: I use a bum bag for passport and wallet. Always use it when out and about. But only the essentials, so it doesn't look bulky. You can't see it under the jacket and I always have cash in my pockets if I go shopping I don't have to fiddle about with the bum bag.
data.author: Sindy Sindy

data.text: Nothing hanging around your neck, last thing you want to do when riding a bike. I put all my stuff in a top tube bag, I just take it all out and put it in my pockets when away from the bike.
data.author: Andy Jackson

data.text: I keep that stuff in my handle bar bag and it just clips off so I take it into shops and stuff when I leave my bike somewhere.
data.author: Nelson Incog Nito

data.text: same. Been on the road for 5 months now and had no problem with this method.
data.author: Kim Mcfadden

data.text: I just finished a month long tour and rode in mountain bike shorts that had zipper pockets in the back and side. I kept my wallet in passport in them and it worked great.
data.author: Scott Hyman

data.text: I do too. Most risk free and convenient solution by far. Bags can easily get stolen (eg thieves on motor bikes) and can be misplaced left behind when tired, disoriented or distracted and then you’ve lost everything at once. Any bag just screams “tourist - all my stuff is in here!” No one is going to steal your shorts … unless you’re a very, very heavy sleeper. 😉
data.author: Martin Jenkins

data.text: I have everything in my waterprood handlebar bag. It never leaves my side. Ever. I am on a solo tour since 3 weeks. Whenever I have to go to a grocery store, I take a cart and put the bag and tripod inside there, so it's easy to carry around. Don't have anything around your neck tho!
data.author: Roberto Hamar

data.text: I wear mine in a money belt. I carry daily expense money in a wallet that is accessible
data.author: Wayne Macdougall

data.text: I had a secured waist bag that lived in my handlebar bag which was locked onto the bike. The waist bag came with me for short stops or going into shops. So if my bike got taken or raided I would always have those things with me. When staying in larger towns or dodgy areas and going out on foot, I tucked the waist bag into a scrappy looking nylon shopping shoulder bag that wouldn’t ID me as a tourist or look like a thief magnet.
data.author: Diane Ridgway

data.text: Get a good handle bar bag I got a small one that when you take it off it turns into a bum bag so you keep money passport keys and phone so when you stop you just take it and go
data.author: John Drennan

data.text: I carried mine in a front pannier and was very aware of it. Extra cash somewhere else. Passport copies i could show to official that might not hand back my passport without a bribe My

data.text: I wear a Fanny pack/hydration pack, which is where I keep *all* of my things like that. It’s a “if Armageddon happens, grab the red bag”. Keep a small prescription bottle with a couple doses of common meds as well. Makes convenient to secure bike, and grab-and-go my things when visiting museums, etc.
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: I use an Osprey backpack that’s designed for bicyclist. It hangs higher on your back and you don’t notice it. Frame pack so stays off your back and doesn’t make you sweat. I keep my wallet, phone, journal, snacks in there etc.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: I've always kept these things in an inner pocket of a jacket or coat when travelling. Once slept with these inside the coat overnight on a ferry. For bikepacking/touring, I store the coat with the things in a handlebar bag if it's too hot to wear, and take the coat with me going into a shop, etc.
data.author: Deirdre Clifford

data.text: Don't put them on your bike, thieves don't care if you get hurt when they knock and grab your stuff. They will grab anything of value as you ride by or when you stop and you look the other way, beware thieves work in pairs and groups, the worst distract you while another grabs your stuff. Bottom line, keep your documents on your person and protected from rain and your sweat. Thieves know all about bicycle tourists carrying cash, ATM cards, expensive phones, watches, cameras, and GPS stuff. Be safe and be aware.
data.author: Clyde Slade

data.text: Always on my person.

data.text: Little "day" purse, coins and say 20 Euro. Another wallet with cards, money etc, in a dry bag with passports, Covid papers, driving licences, basically anything that we really don't want to lose and if everything else gets nicked we can survive with the dry bag! In South America when we were going through dodgy places I had a plastic wallet in my bra with a credit card and 100 USD to get us out of trouble if needed (never did). Front bar pouch for mobile, suncream and bits 🤗

data.text: passport in shorts pocket. Money in ba bag. All fine so far.
data.author: Triss Pollington

data.text: We’ve toured many years by tandem. When traveling abroad by tandem, my husband will carry our passports in a small pouch that he wears around his neck. I carry the money and cards in a wallet, with an Apple tag, in our frame bag. We also have dropped an Apple tag in the frame bag, so we can track the location of our bike if has to be parked away from us. Also found it very useful to: Store pictures of passports, ID, cards, Covid card, etc on one’s phone.
data.author: Sara Jane Westerdale-Nelson

data.text: Handlebar bag carries my camera, phone, wallet, passport, everything I can't afford to lose. When I get off the bike, the handlebar bag gets off with me. Mine has a shoulder strap, so it's easy to carry. I keep it with me at all times.
data.author: Murray Sovereign

data.text: Also take photos of all your critical ID, and carry printed copies in a different bag. Keep photos on your phone, and email them to yourself so you can retrieve them in case your phone dies or gets lost.
data.author: Murray Sovereign

data.text: I had all the thinks in my pants last year, but that wasn't comfortable. Now I have 1/2 of it in my VAUDE handlebar bag and the other 1/2 in my VAUDE backpack. It has 12 l only, but anyway a waist belt. I also carry a Camelbak in it. The backpack is perfekt for cycling. *in one of them my passport, in the other one a copy of my passport. Furthermore I have a copy of my passport in my panniers.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: Bumbag has all valuables, so wherever I go they're with me. Photocopies of vital stuff are at the bottom of a pannier. A bar bag works too,
data.author: Sue Mosley

data.text:
Cash I spread around. Some on my person, some in my handlebar bag, some in a pannier. When I have to carry a passport, I tend to put it in my handlebar bag, as I find it a bit too big to put in pockets, as I worry about bending and damaging my passport. It is also in a ziploc type bag with other docs I need, to keep it all dry. If I am just travelling I carry my passport in an undergarment neck wallet thing that is very thin soft sided and has no sharp corners, I don't even realise it is there. Similar to the one in the link below. I put important docs in a ziploc bag to keep them dry, incase of rain or sweat. https://www.amazon.com/Travelon-RFID-Blocking-Undergarment-Pouch/dp/B01EAFBDDS/ref=sr_1_24?crid=GM9517ERE4FF&keywords=travel%2Bpouch%2Bfor%2Bdocuments%2Bneck&qid=1656823761&sprefix=travel%2Bpouch%2Bfor%2Bdocuments%2Bneck%2Caps%2C301&sr=8-24&th=1 When I carry just cards and an ID card, I have a little card holder on a paracord around my neck. This also has emergency info printed on a piece of paper

data.text: Topeak bar bag - unclips in seconds at cafe etc
data.author: John DC

data.text: Neck wallet, but INSIDE your clothing. Mine never comes off my neck unless I'm in the shower, when it's inside the cubicle with me. If in a sleeping bag, it's in the bottom of the bag, where my feet are. Bar bags and the like are easily put on the floor and forgotten, as I once did, only to have a kind person ask if the bag was mine as I walked away, from it and the money, air tickets, passport etc inside it! Cameras etc that are lost won't destroy your holiday, you can always buy another. But loss of cash, money and passport will stop you dead in your tracks.

data.text: Put them where you can find them.
